Given a probability space $S, \mathcal{F}, P$ and two events $A\in \mathcal{F}$ and $B \in \mathcal{F}$, $A$ and $B$ are statistically independent if and only if (iff)

$$ P(A \cap B) = P(A)P(B).$$

Given a probability space $S, \mathcal{F}, P$, events $E_0, E_1, \ldots E_{n-1}$ in $\mathcal{F}$ are statistically independent iff \begin{align} &P(E_i \cap E_j) = P(E_i) P(E_j), ~~ \scriptstyle \forall i \ne j \\ & P(E_i \cap E_j \cap E_k) = P(E_i) P(E_j) P(E_k), ~~ \scriptstyle \forall i \ne j \ne k \\ & \scriptstyle \ldots \\ & \scriptstyle P(E_0 \cap E_1 \cap \ldots \cap E_{n-1}) \, = \, P(E_0) P(E_1) \cdots P(E_{n-1}), \\ \end{align}

Given a probability space $S, \mathcal{F}, P$, a collection of events $E_0, E_1, \ldots E_{n-1}$ in $\mathcal{F}$ are pairwise statistically independent iff \begin{align} P(E_i \cap E_j) &= P(E_i) P(E_j), ~~ \forall i \ne j \end{align}

Remember:
m.e. is a set relation
s.i. is a probability relation
Events cannot be both s.i. and m.e. unless at least one has prob. zero.
